awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Production of "South-South" Capitalist Labor Relations
awd_abstract_narration:
Foreign commercial and investment activities in developing countries are no longer exclusively owned and managed by traditional core countries of the Global North, such as the United States and Britain. Increasingly, countries of the Global South are leading the way. For example, China and India have been at the forefront of commercial activities in sub-Saharan Africa. These investments have generated needed jobs for poor countries but they also have produced controversies about labor practices. One question that has arisen is whether national and international labor codes are being ignored to give businesses unfair advantages while also victimizing workers. However, surprisingly little is known about how the situation plays out on the ground, at the work sites where workers and foreign supervisors actually engage. The research supported by this award will help to fill this knowledge gap. This research is in the United States' national interest because the U.S. government and investors need to know that they are playing on a level playing field. It also is essential to better understand the contexts that determine the effectiveness of U.S. foreign aid investments.

This fourteen month empirical ethnographic study will be carried out by University of California, Davis, anthropology doctoral student, Justin L. Haruyama, under the supervision of Dr. James H. Smith. The research will be conducted in two Chinese-operated coal mines in southern Zambia: one operated by a Chinese state-owned enterprise and the other privately owned by five Chinese brothers. Both of these mines hire managers primarily from China while recruiting their ordinary workforces exclusively from Zambia and neighboring African countries. The research will examine how actors from different racial, linguistic, and cultural backgrounds at the mines understand and affect each other. This will illuminate the broader social consequences and capitalist transformations at work in everyday encounters around the extraction of coal. The researcher will also pay close attention to historical experience, as preliminary research has shown that the sometimes-traumatic encounters with colonialism, socialism, and neoliberalism experienced by participants from both Zambia and China continue to have profound reverberations in their actions and discourses at the mines today. Data will be collected through a mixed-methods approach, including archival research, participant observation, census and structured survey interviews, and the collection of life histories. Results from this research will improve understanding of how contemporary international capitalist investments are affecting the lives of ordinary people, and how they are reshaping business environments and capitalist culture in many African countries.

por.por_cntn:
This project involved fourteen months from June 2017 to August 2018 of ethnographic investigation into two Chinese-operated coal mines in southern Zambia: one operated by a Chinese state-owned enterprise (SOE), and the other privately owned by five brothers from China's Jiangxi Province. The research examined how actors from various racial, linguistic, and cultural backgrounds at the mines struggle to understand and regulate each other's presence, thereby illuminating the broader capitalist transformations at work in everyday encounters around the extraction of coal. Existing global accounts of shifts in capitalism to a more South-dominated world lack an ethnographically-nuanced account of how these processes are experienced and understood by local actors on the ground, an account that this project will provide. To do so, this project will has paid close attention to historical experience, as preliminary research showed that the sometimes-traumatic encounters with colonialism, socialism, and neoliberalism experienced by participants from both Zambia and China continue to have profound reverberations in their actions and discourses at the mines today.

The rise in recent decades of economic giants from the global south, such as China, India, Brazil, and South Africa, has transformed a global capitalist system from one dominated by a Euro-American "core" to a more multipolar arrangement with multiple centers and unevenly intersecting peripheries. While tremendous amounts of popular and scholarly work have been devoted to these processes at a global scale, detailed ethnographic analyses of how these macro processes are actually working themselves out on the local level and shaping the concrete lives of their participants have been thin. In the case of contemporary Chinese activities in Africa specifically, the few extant ethnographic accounts (e.g. Lee 2014) have tended to focus on the operation of Chinese state-owned enterprises (SOEs) and to have ignored the perhaps even more significant operation of Chinese private capital on the continent. By engaging in a detailed comparative ethnographic study of both a Chinese SOE-operated mine and a private, family-owned mine in Zambia, this study provides a richly nuanced account of how transformations in both global capitalism and Chinese capitalist activities specifically are playing themselves out at the local level. It will also highlight how African practices and everyday African- Chinese interactions impact the implementation of Chinese capitalism on the ground.

Many countries in the world today are grappling with rising xenophobia and tensions, sometimes even violence, between migrant populations and host country communities. These tensions are exacerbated by the vagaries of contemporary neoliberal capitalism, as people around the world experience rapid changes in economic fortune: the negative repercussions of which are easy to pin on outsiders. Nevertheless, the arrival of over a million Chinese migrants to Africa in the last decade--and the profound ways in which this large-scale population movement is reconfiguring capitalist relations in the region--has received very little sustained scholarly attention. By providing a nuanced understanding of how individual participants' layered experiences of history shapes how these large-scale shifts in global capitalism work themselves out on the ground, this project will be transformative for research as well as policy and civil society conversations in Africa and similar contexts globally. To contribute to policy and intervention conversations, I collaborated with the scholars at the University of Zambia (UNZA) and the Southern Africa Institute for Policy and Research (SAIPAR) to present my research findings and contribute to their public discussions and publications. I also continued to disseminate my research more widely through publication of my findings in easily-accessible journals and through presentation at conferences in the US and abroad. Further, drawing on my Peace Corps experience and my years of university teaching, I mentored students at the University of Zambia, training them in academic writing and qualitative research methods. This will allow them to build valuable skills not only for advocating for themselves to policymakers in Zambia but also for seeking employment in the government, in NGOs, in community-based organizations, or in academic institutions abroad.
